org.schwering.evi.core
Interface IApplet

public interface IApplet

ModuleClass interface for tiny applets.

This interface must be implemented by modules which want to display a small panel at the main application's toolbar. This small panel is typically at the top right. It is always displayed, even if the owning module is not "on top".

This interface does not extend IModule. The reason is that IApplet's function is quite analogous to IPanel's. IPanel itself is does not extend IModule; because also non-module-classes might want to be IPanels. While this doesn't make much sense for IApplet, IApplet is still very similar to IPanel in its idea and therefore it does not extend IModule either.
To put it in a nutshell: Modules that are inteded to display an applet should implement both, IModule and IApplet.

Version:
$Id$
Author:
Christoph Schwering (mailto:schwering@gmail.com)
See Also:
ModuleContainer.isApplet()

Method Summary
 void dispose()
          Should clean up used resources when the panel is shut down.
 java.awt.Component getAppletInstance()
          Returns a reference to the module instance's applet part as Component.
 

Method Detail

getAppletInstance

public java.awt.Component getAppletInstance()
Returns a reference to the module instance's applet part as Component. Each invokation of getAppletInstance must return a reference to the same object. This means that this method must not create a new applet but return just a reference to a once created java.awt.Component.

If the implementing module class extends java.awt.Component (e.g. if it extends javax.swing.JPanel) this method simply might return this.

Returns:
The concrete applet-part as java.awt.Component.

dispose

public void dispose()
Should clean up used resources when the panel is shut down.

This method is also declared in IModule (IModule.dispose()). This makes it easy to write an applet module that implements both, IModule and IApplet. See these weird explanations.

See Also:
IModule.dispose()
